children.value: Before you start building your first Gatsby site, you‚Äôll need to familiarize yourself with some core web technologies and make sure that you have installed all required software tools.

It‚Äôs not necessary to be an expert with these already ‚Äî if you‚Äôre not, don‚Äôt worry! You‚Äôll pick up a lot through the course of this tutorial series. These are some of the main web technologies you‚Äôll use when building a Gatsby site:

: A markup language that every web browser is able to understand. It stands for HyperText Markup Language. HTML gives your web content a universal informational structure, defining things like headings, paragraphs, and more.
: A presentational language used to style the appearance of your web content (fonts, colors, layout, etc). It stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
: A programming language that helps us make the web dynamic and interactive.
: A code library (built with JavaScript) for building user interfaces. It‚Äôs the framework that Gatsby uses to build pages and structure content.
: A query language. A programming language that allows you to pull data into your website. It‚Äôs the interface that Gatsby uses for managing site data.
üí° (Optional!) For a comprehensive introduction to what a website is‚Äîincluding an intro to HTML and CSS‚Äîcheck out ‚Äú
‚Äù. It‚Äôs a great place to start learning about the web. For a more hands-on introduction to
, check out the tutorials from Codecademy.
also have their own introductory tutorials.

hProperties.aria-label: familiarize yourself with the command line permalink

children.value: Familiarize yourself with the command line

The command line is a text-based interface used to run commands on your computer. You‚Äôll also often see it referred to as the terminal. In this tutorial we‚Äôll use both interchangeably. It‚Äôs a lot like using the Finder on a Mac or Explorer on Windows. Finder and Explorer are examples of graphical user interfaces (GUI). The command line is a powerful, text-based way to interact with your computer.
Take a moment to locate and open up the command line interface (CLI) for your computer. Depending on which operating system you are using, see
üí° For a great introduction to using the command line, check out
for Mac and Linux users, and
for Windows users. Even if you are a Windows user, the first page of the Codecademy tutorial is a valuable read. It explains what the command line is, not just how to interface with it.

Node.js is an environment that can run JavaScript code outside of a web browser. Gatsby is built with Node.js. To get up and running with Gatsby, you‚Äôll need to have a recent version installed on your computer.
Note: Gatsby‚Äôs minimum supported Node.js version is Node 8, but feel free to use a more recent version.
and follow the instructions to download and install the recommended version for your operating system. Once you have followed the installation steps, make sure everything was installed properly:
. (If you‚Äôre new to the command line, ‚Äúrun
in the command prompt, and hit the Enter key‚Äù. From here on, this is what we mean by ‚Äúrun

The output of each of those commands should be a version number. Your versions may not be the same as those shown below! If entering those commands doesn‚Äôt show you a version number, go back and make sure you have installed Node.js.

children.alt: Check node and npm versions in terminal

children.value: npm is a JavaScript package manager. A package is a module of code that you can choose to include in your projects. If you just downloaded and installed Node.js, npm was installed with it!
npm has three distinct components: the npm website, the npm registry, and the npm command line interface (CLI).
On the npm website, you can browse what JavaScript packages are available in the npm registry.
The npm registry is a large database of information about JavaScript packages available on npm.

Once you‚Äôve identified a package you want, you can use the npm CLI to install it in your project or globally (like other CLI tools). The npm CLI is what talks to the registry ‚Äî you generally only interact with the npm website or the npm CLI.

Git is a free and open source distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency. When you install a Gatsby ‚Äústarter‚Äù site, Gatsby uses Git behind the scenes to download and install the required files for your starter. You will need to have Git installed to set up your first Gatsby site.
The steps to download and install Git depend on your operating system. Follow the guide for your system:
üí° You will not need to know Git to complete this tutorial, but it is a very useful tool. If you are interested in learning more about version control, Git, and GitHub, check out GitHub‚Äôs

The Gatsby CLI tool lets you quickly create new Gatsby-powered sites and run commands for developing Gatsby sites. It is a published npm package. Rather than installing the Gatsby CLI tool locally you can run it using
To see the commands available to run
üí° If you are unable to successfully run npx due to a permissions issue, you may want to check out the

Now you are ready to use the Gatsby CLI tool to create your first Gatsby site. Using the tool, you can download ‚Äústarters‚Äù (partially built sites with some default configuration) to help you get moving faster on creating a certain type of site. The ‚ÄúHello World‚Äù starter you‚Äôll be using here is a starter with the bare essentials needed for a Gatsby site.
Note: Depending on your download speed, the amount of time this takes will vary. For brevity‚Äôs sake, the gif below was paused during part of the install
npx gatsby new hello-world https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-hello-world
executes an npm package binary without installing it locally.
tells npx, ‚Äòhey, we want to use the gatsby-cli tool!‚Äô.
is a gatsby command to create a new Gatsby project.
is an arbitrary title ‚Äî you could pick anything. The CLI tool will place the code for your new site in a new folder called ‚Äúhello-world‚Äù.
Lastly, the GitHub URL specified points to a code repository that holds the starter code you want to use.
cd hello-world
This says ‚ÄòI want to change directories (

) to the ‚Äúhello-world‚Äù subfolder‚Äô. Whenever you want to run any commands for your site, you need to be in the context for that site (aka, your terminal needs to be pointed at the directory where your site code lives).
npm run develop
This command starts a development server. You will be able to see and interact with your new site in a development environment ‚Äî local (on your computer, not published to the internet).
Open up a new tab in your browser and navigate to
Congrats! This is the beginning of your very first Gatsby site! üéâ
You‚Äôll be able to visit the site locally at
for as long as your development server is running. That‚Äôs the process you started by running the

command. To stop running that process (or to ‚Äústop running the development server‚Äù), go back to your terminal window, hold down the ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù key, and then hit ‚Äúc‚Äù (ctrl-c). To start it again, run
If you are using VM setup like
and/or would like to listen on your local IP address, run
. Now, the development server listens on both ‚Äòlocalhost‚Äô and your local IP.

hProperties.aria-label: set up a code editor permalink

children.value: A code editor is a program designed specifically for editing computer code. There are many great ones out there.
If you haven‚Äôt worked with a code editor before, we recommend
, simply because the screenshots used throughout the tutorial will match, and may be easier to follow.

Gatsby documentation sometimes includes screenshots of code editors; these screenshots show the VS Code editor, so if you don‚Äôt have a preferred code editor yet, using VS Code will make sure that your screen looks just like the screenshots in the tutorial and docs. If you choose to use VS Code, visit the
and download the version appropriate for your platform.
‚Äî Prettier is a tool that helps format your code, keeping it consistent and helping to avoid errors.
You can use Prettier directly in your editor using the
Open the extensions view on VS Code (View => Extensions).
Click ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù. After installation you‚Äôll be prompted to restart VS Code to enable the extension.
üí° If you‚Äôre not using VS Code, check out the Prettier docs for
To summarize, in this section you:
Learned about web technologies used with Gatsby (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React, and GraphQL)
Learned about the command line and how to use it
Installed and learned about Node.js and the npm CLI tool, the version control system Git, and the Gatsby CLI tool
Generated a new Gatsby site using the Gatsby CLI tool
Ran the Gatsby development server and visited your site locally
Installed a code formatter called Prettier
getting to know Gatsby building blocks
